Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Broadening Participation. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow and a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Michael Gil is "Effects of prey social context on predator-prey interactions and community stability in coral reefs." The host institution for this fellowship is The University of California at Davis, and the sponsoring scientists include Andy Sih (primary), Marissa Baskett, and Mullica Jaroensutasinee (Walailak University, Thailand).

In a variety of ecosystems, prey have been shown to rapidly propagate danger reactions and signals, across species and wide spatial ranges, by incidentally providing information to one another, e.g., by evading a predator. Prey behavior that results from this social information may have important consequences for predator-prey interactions and, ultimately, the structure of the greater community. In coral reefs, where mixed-species prey fishes consume algae that drive coral declines, social information shared among prey could influence global coral reef degradation to alga-dominated states. The fellowship research uses field experimentation, assisted by computer vision technology, combined with mathematical simulation modeling to examine the behavioral and ecological effects of social information in mixed-species reef fish assemblages. This integrated approach is revealing important insights regarding the role of social information in the dynamics and function of animal communities, a topic of general conservation concern that is largely unexplored in most taxa. Further, it elucidates mechanisms underlying community stability in coral reefs, a topic that continues to perplex researchers.

Training goals include emphasis on quantitative methods and the study of animal behavior to formulate and parameterize a mathematical model for predicting the effects of social information on predator, prey, and resource dynamics. Public outreach includes creating micro-narrative films that educate a diverse public audience of non-scientists on core concepts in ecology/animal behavior and on what science and a career therein actually entail. These products are to be distributed through a variety of outlets, including an interactive public science communication website (co-administered with students) and lectures given to high schools with large populations of under-represented students. An international collaboration is being established between UC Davis and Walailak University (Thailand) whose benefits include ongoing ecological monitoring in Thailand and informing conservation efforts in socioeconomically invaluable coral reef ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How social interactions among wild animals can shape ecosystems

Like human societies, animal communities function as networks of individuals interconnected by information channels. Through their presence and behaviors, such as feeding from a location or fleeing from a predator, animals produce ‘social information’ that can alert nearby individuals, even of different species, to resources or danger. In the work I have conducted in my NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship, my colleagues and I have developed empirical and theoretical approaches that have revealed important ecological consequences of social information use in wild animal populations and communities.

 

Intellectual Merit

Our research findings have revealed general and system-specific ecological consequences of animal social information use, broadly informing the fields of ecology, animal behavior, and natural resource management. Using a combination of mathematical models and a synthesis of the current literature, we have demonstrated that animals simply using the flight responses of others as early warnings of shared danger, a ubiquitous phenomenon in nature, can have profound effects on individual behavior, fitness and long-term population dynamics. Specifically, we have shown that social information, alone, can drive positive density dependence in the growth rate of not only populations but also communities of wild animals. In extreme cases, social information can cause critical thresholds in population growth trajectories, whereby below a certain population size, there is insufficient social information to allow the population to grow (e.g., when food is scarce, or predators are abundant). Under such circumstances, declining populations (e.g., due to hunting or habitat loss) can rapidly and unexpectedly collapse, since the loss of each information-producing individual is increasingly detrimental to the vulnerable population. Further, because social information allows animals to help one another survive, it can shape species interactions. For example, social information shared within a population of a single species can make this population more competitive against rival species; however, conversely, social information shared between populations of two or more species can reduce between-species competition and promote species coexistence. These findings resulted in two publications, both in high-impact journals (Trends in Ecology & Evolution and The American Naturalist), on which I served as lead author. I have also authored a third  manuscript that delves deeper into the theory of social information effects on populations, soon to be submitted to the high-impact journal Ecology Letters.

In addition to the contributions my work has made through synthesis and theoretical modeling, I have also developed empirical approaches to examine social information use in a specific system of key socioeconomic importance: mixed-species assemblages of fish in coral reefs. These fish consume algae that elicit a suite of lethal effects on corals, which form the basis for the greater ecosystem. Our work has revealed that social information could be responsible for over 60% of this algal consumption and, thus, may raise, beyond previous expectations, the vulnerability of coral reefs to disturbances like overfishing (i.e., fish removal also means information loss for survivors). These findings resulted in a publication, which I led, in the high-impact journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. This work directly motivated three additional manuscripts (one in review at PNAS, two in prep) that have revealed mechanistic drivers and asymmetries (across species) of social information use in coral reef fish communities. Collectively, these findings point to social information as an important though largely overlooked driver of ecological dynamics, and one that could be critical to consider in conservation and natural resource management.

 

Broader Impacts

In addition to the extensive quantitative training I received as part of my NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship, this fellowship allowed me to establish a new field research program, in collaboration with a Thai NGO and Thai scientists from Walailak University, to study the vastly under-studied, yet economically critical coral reefs of the Gulf of Thailand. In this region, I delivered 4 public talks to familiarize stakeholders with the motivations and findings of my research and how they can be useful to local conservation and resource management activities. In addition, the scientific discoveries described above motivated 19 talks that I gave to academic and public audiences. Furthermore, as part of my fellowship, I formally taught a field research course to a diverse class of undergraduates in Mexico, I served as a formal mentor to the undergraduate group ‘SEEDS’ (Strategies for Ecology Education, Diversity and Sustainability) that promotes diversity in STEM, I mentored graduate students in research approaches (including students from groups underrepresented in STEM), and I developed and published 84 science outreach videos on YouTube and Facebook, as part of the organization SciAll.org (a 501(c)3 nonprofit) that I founded and direct. My research and outreach efforts motivated my selection as a TED Fellow and a National Geographic Explorer, institutional affiliations that have already greatly facilitated the dissemination of my research discoveries and outreach products to a broad, international audience.
